TEXT: The applicant , Mr Rastislav Machunka , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the Court by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . ORG of GPE ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
On DATE the applicant filed an action for protection of his personal rights with ORG . He sued the editor of a DATE newspaper which had allegedly made defamatory statements about him .

On DATE ORG invited the applicant to pay the court fee . On DATE the applicant informed ORG in writing that he had transferred the sum due on DATE . As ORG did not receive the sum , the applicant was heard on DATE . It was established that the sum had been returned to the applicant ’s account . On DATE ORG received the fee .
On DATE ORG asked the defendant to submit comments on the action within DATE .
According to a note in the case file , the judge dealing with the case had been attached temporarily to a different court starting on DATE .
On DATE the ORG delivered a judgment against which both parties appealed on DATE and on DATE respectively .

After having taken several procedural steps ORG submitted the case file to ORG on DATE . On DATE ORG returned the file to ORG as there had been shortcomings in serving the first - instance judgment . On DATE ORG sent the judgment to the party concerned . That party filed an appeal on DATE . On DATE the file was re - submitted to the appellate court .

On DATE ORG quashed ORG judgment of DATE . The appellate court found that ORG had committed a serious procedural mistake in that its decision exceeded the scope of the case . The question whether the defendant had standing in the case was also to be clarified and further evidence was to be taken . The file was returned to ORG on DATE . ORG decision was served on the parties on DATE and on DATE respectively .

On DATE the applicant withdrew a part of his claim which concerned an apology for the statements in question . He explained that DATE had lapsed since their publication . The applicant maintained his claim for compensation amounting to the equivalent of MONEY ( ORG ) .
On DATE ORG admitted another person as a defendant in the proceedings .
ORG made several inquiries , in accordance with ORG instructions , DATE .
On DATE the case was assigned to a different judge as the judge dealing with it had been transferred to a different court .
On DATE ORG made further written inquiries to which it received replies on CARDINAL and DATE .
On DATE ORG scheduled a hearing for DATE . It also made inquiries with a view to obtaining further evidence .
On DATE the applicant asked for the hearing scheduled for DATE to be adjourned due to the absence of his lawyer .
A hearing was scheduled for DATE . The defendant asked for its adjournment as his lawyer could not attend . He further requested that no hearing be scheduled for DATE .
On DATE ORG asked the police for assistance in serving a summons on a witness . On DATE the police replied that they had been unable to serve the summons .

At the hearing held on DATE the applicant withdrew his claim against the second defendant . After the decision to discontinue the relevant part of the proceedings had become final on DATE , the court scheduled a hearing for DATE . On the last mentioned date the case was adjourned as a witness failed to appear .
A hearing scheduled for DATE was adjourned as the judge was ill .

On DATE both the defendant and a witness failed to appear . The court imposed a procedural fine of CARDINAL NORP korunas on the witness . It asked the Bratislava I ORG to hear the witness . On DATE the Bratislava I ORG informed ORG that the witness had not appeared before it and that neither the post office nor the police had been able to serve the summons on her .
Subsequently the case was assigned to a different judge as the judge originally appointed to deal with it was on maternity leave .
The hearing scheduled for DATE was adjourned to CARDINAL DATE at the request of the applicant ’s lawyer .
On DATE ORG delivered a judgment in which it granted the applicant ’s claim in part . The judgment became final on DATE .

On DATE the applicant complained about the length of the proceedings before ORG to ORG . He claimed , inter alia , the equivalent of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL as financial compensation . On DATE ORG declared the complaint admissible .

On DATE ORG found that ORG had violated the applicant ’s right to a hearing without unjustified delay . It instructed ORG to proceed with the case without any further delay and awarded the equivalent of LAW by way of just satisfaction to the applicant , payable within DATE . It also ordered ORG to reimburse the costs of the applicant ’s legal representation within DATE .

The decision stated that the case was of a certain procedural complexity and that what was at stake for the applicant called for the particular attention of the court dealing with it . In ORG view , the applicant was responsible for the delayed payment of the court fee , as a result of which DATE had lapsed before ORG could start proceeding with the case . On the other hand , several delays occurred subsequently for which ORG was responsible . In particular , DATE had lapsed DATE ( when the court fee was paid ) and DATE ( when ORG effectively started dealing with the case ) . Undue delay occurred DATE and DATE because of the erroneous service of the first - instance judgment . ORG found further delays in the proceedings after DATE when ORG had returned the case file to ORG .
